column4: hi - whats the best way of creating an admin user along with the user group "admin" or "admins" with associated privileges (not graphically, but in the shell)
unfortunately, the only stnadard user group which could serve is adm
Don't use adm for that - adm has a very standard purpose: "Can read system logs"
hm maxb - how then ?
well, what do you mean by admin user? That's "root", surely?
if you like, I want a root user, with same right, except that they need to do "sudo" for system tasks like mounting a new device
or mapping it
so... you want a normal user that is authorized to sudo?
but basically I want them to be able to inspect e.g. the svn directory and write there
: well, yes - would you recommend that ?
I want my team to be able to be admin on this server
so I think the best approach would be to create admin accounts for them
Have you noticed that Ubuntu ships with an 'admin' group which has the right to sudo, by default? :-)
well not on mine
I did a vi /etc/groups
hmm, how odd
there is no admin group there
sorry
vi /etc/group
Well, you don't even need a group, really, you can just grant authority to individual users in /etc/sudoers
oh ok
is there a howto for that somewhere ?

I agree sudoers is a fairly mindbending file format, but I'd still suggest reading "man sudoers". By way of an example:   root,maxb,%admin ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD: ALL      means that root, maxb, and people in the admin group can run, on ALL hosts (that's a feature to allow a single sudoers file to be shared for a whole network), as ALL (any) user, ALL (any) command, without needing to confirm their password
